items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director 
of Instructional Services
SUBJECT:
Consideration of Petition for Proposed ACE Charter High School
	 
	 
On September 16, 2011, the District received a charter petition from ACE Charter School Board of Directors.  The Petition proposes to establish ACE Charter High School in the East Side Union High School District Mayfair Community serving students in 9th through 12th grades.  The Petition proposes to begin with 9th and 10th grades in fall of 2012-13 and add a grade level each year until it services all grades 9th and 12th in August/September 2015.
	 
The District held a public hearing on the Petition as required by law during the public session of the Board Meeting on October 20, 2011.
	 
At the public hearing, Greg Lippman, Executive Director of ACE Charter High School, presented information about the proposed charter.  In addition, several parents who reside in the East Side Union High School District addressed the Board to express their interest in sending their children to the proposed charter school.  Marisa Hanson, President of the East Side Teachers' Association spoke in support of East Side Union High School District traditional school and services.
	 
The District must now either grant or deny the charter petition.  The District may grant the charter “if it is satisfied that granting the charter is consistent with sound educational practice.”  The District may not deny a petition for the establishment of a charter school unless it makes written factual findings, specific to the particular petition, setting forth specific facts to support one or more of the following findings:
	 
The charter school presents an unsound educational program for pupils to be enrolled in the charter school;
The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition;
The petition does not contain the required number of signatures;
The petition does not contain an affirmation of each of the required conditions set forth in section 47605(d); or
The petition does not contain reasonable comprehensive descriptions of the 15 elements of a charter school set forth in Education Code Section 47605(b)
	 
If the Board makes one or more of these five findings, it must also adopt written factual findings that are specific to the issues raised in this particular Petition.
	 
The District's Charter Proposal Evaluation Team carefully reviewed and analyzed the Petition, and met with representatives from ACE Charter High School in order to discuss their petition.  A subcommittee of the evaluation team also visited ACE Charter High School.  As set forth in the attached Proposed Findings, Administration recommends that the ACE Charter High School Charter Petition be granted,
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE
General Fund
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
If approved there will be fiscal impact.  The anticipated fiscal impact is not subject to quantification at this time due to the varying uncertainties with state funding, actual charter operations and the extent to which the charter school draws upon non-reimbursable District services.
	 
	 
	 
 
RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees give careful consideration to this Petition and the concerns raised by the Administration.  If the Boards acts to deny the Petition, the Board should adopt the attached Findings as support for the Board’s decision.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees give careful consideration to this Petition and the concerns raised by the Charter Petition Review Team. If the Board acts to deny the Petition, the Board should adopt the attached Charter Petition Review Team Report and the findings included therein.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  9.02
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation of District Life Insurance Plan Changes
			 
The district currently provides district paid life insurance coverage to all employees and Board Members at a current benefit level of $25,000 through Standard insurance.  The total annual premium rate for this level of coverage totals $96,645.  The District’s current life insurance coverage was last marketed in 2002. Based on a  favorable life insurance  environment, the district requested that Gallagher Benefit Services market the district to other carriers. The market was very competitive and the district received 12 life insurance quotes.  A review of the quotes and resulting negotiations determined that Unum Insurance was the most favorable for the district. Unum insurance plan increases each employee and Board Members life insurance coverage from $25,000 to $40,000.  In addition, Unum has offered to replace the district’s current employee assistance program (EAP) through Ceridian with their own EAP program which is also with Ceridian at no costs to the district. The benefit coverage remains unchanged and employees will not experience any difference in the plans.  Since Unum Insurance is including the EAP in their life program, the change from Standard Insurance to Unum Insurance will result in a net savings to the district of $62,648 annually and a higher benefit level for each employee.  
			 
In addition to the district’s basic life insurance coverage, each employee and Board Member will have the option to purchase optional voluntary life coverage for themselves, their spouse and children. The coverage is very inexpensive and provides a guaranteed issuance of $200,000 for the employee, $50,000 for a spouse, and $10,000 per child with no questions asked.   The voluntary life program is portable and employees would have an opportunity to retain the coverage for themselves and their family should they leave the district’s employment.   
			 
The plan changes would take effect on January 1, 2012 for the district coverage.  The voluntary life program will be marketed for a March 1, 2012 implementation and would be contingent upon at least 15% of the districts employees signing up
FISCAL IMPACT:
$62,648.00 (Annual Savings)
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not Applicable

This is an overview of the National School Lunch and School Breakfast Programs.  East Side Union High School District serves over 3,000 breakfasts, and 5,000 lunches per day to students.  These meals are an essential component to the success of their educational day.  With the economy in its current state it is especially important to provide nutritious meals that are appetizing, as well as affordable.

items.item_details:
Board Meeting of November 17, 2011
Item:  9.09
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
SENATE CONSTITUTION AMENDMENT 5 (Simitian) (SCA 5)
Resolution #2011/2012-12
	 
	 
WHEREAS, Senate Constitutional Amendment 5 (Simitian), which reduces the two-thirds vote requirement on parcel taxes, will be acted on by the California State Legislature; and 
	 
WHEREAS, reductions in the State general fund revenue have led to reduced school funding, and
	 
WHEREAS, State general fund revenue is unstable and erratic, which results in unprecedented funding levels for school districts and county offices of education; and 
	 
WHEREAS, parcel tax revenue can provide a stable, predictable source of school revenue; and
	 
WHEREAS, passage of SCA 5 will empower local voters to invest in their schools based on the needs of their communities by requiring a  tough, but fair, 55 percent vote to pass local parcel taxes, while protecting taxpayers and homeowners with accountability provisions that will ensure that funds generated from parcel taxes are not wasted or mismanaged; and
	 
WHEREAS, revenue from parcel taxes can be spent according to local priorities and are not subject to State control; and
	 
WHEREAS, the two-thirds vote requirement results in minority rule by requiring two "yes" votes to cancel out one "no" vote; and
	 
WHEREAS, passage of SCA 5 will allow local voters to decide to make investments in their neighborhood schools in addition to State funding; and;
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District strongly urges the California State Legislature to support and adopt SCA 5. 
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 17th day of November, 2012, by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.
	AYES: ________
	NOES: ________
	ABSENT: ______
	ABSTAIN: ______
	I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on November 17, 2012.
	_________________________
	Clerk
	ESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.10 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Consideration and Authorization of Hearing Concerning D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. 
Re: Violation of Public Contract Code Sections 4104 and 4106 and Possible Imposition 
of Remedies as Allowed by Law
	 
	 
The Subletting and Subcontracting Fair Practices Act (Public Contract Code Sections 4100 et seq.) requires that a prime contractor on a public works project shall, for each subcontract in excess of ½ of 1% of the prime contractor’s total bid, list in his or her bid each such subcontractor and the portion of the work to be subcontracted to the subcontractor. The Act further provides that if a prime contractor violates the Act, the public agency may cancel the contract or impose a penalty of up to ten percent (10%) of the amount of the subcontracted work at issue.
	 
On June 28, 2011, the Board approved the award of the contract for the Yerba Buena High School Title IX Interior Modernization Project to D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. (“DLF”) in the total amount of $3,509,000.  As required by law, DLF submitted to the District a Designated Subcontractors List specifying each subcontractor on the project and the portion of the work to be performed by the subcontractor.  DLF’s Subcontractor List did not designate any subcontractor for rough framing.
	 
Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 4106, if a prime contractor fails to specify a subcontractor for any portion of work to be performed under the contract which work is in excess of one-half of 1 percent of the prime contractor's total bid, the prime contractor agrees that he or she is fully qualified to perform that portion himself or herself, and that the prime contractor (here, DLF) shall perform that portion himself or herself.  If, after the award of contract, the prime contractor subcontracts any such portion of the work, the prime contractor shall be subject to the penalties named in Sections 4110 and 4111 (grounds for discipline before the State Contractor’s License Board).
	 
Earlier this month the District received information indicating the presence of subcontractors at the Yerba Buena job site not included on DLF’s Subcontractors List and performing work (rough carpentry work) that had not been indicated on the Subcontractor’s List to be performed by any subcontractor.  By letter dated November 4, 2009, the District (by and through FMPO, the District’s construction manager for the project) notified D.L. Falk and requested that DLF provide clarification and information as to the use of undesignated subcontractors at the project site.  A response was received from DLF on November 7, 2011.  (Copies of the letters are attached.)
	 
The District has now received a copy of the subcontract between DLF and subcontractor Argo Construction, Inc. in the amount of $115,000 for “rough carpentry” on the YBHS project.  Argo Construction was not designated by DLF on the Subcontractors List, nor was any subcontractor designated by DLF on the Subcontractor’s List for rough carpentry.  The contract amount ($115,000.00) exceeds the threshold of one-half of one percent for requiring District approval.
	 
Public Contract Code section 4110 provides:
	 
“A prime contractor violating any of the provisions of this chapter violates his or her contract and the awarding authority may exercise the option, in its own discretion, of (1) canceling his or her contract or (2) assessing the prime contractor a penalty in an amount of not more than 10 percent of the amount of the subcontract involved, and this penalty shall be deposited in the fund out of which the prime contract is awarded. In any proceedings under this section the prime contractor shall be entitled to a public hearing and to five days' notice of the time and place thereof.”
	 
All of the above provisions of the Subletting and Subcontracting Fair Practices Act are incorporated into and made a part of the contract between the District and DLF for the YBHS project.
	 
The information received to date raises a serious issue of whether DLF has violated the Subletting and Subcontracting Fair Practices Act provisions noted above.  If so, then the District would be authorized to impose the penalties specified under Public Contract Code section 4110.
	 
Based on the information available to date, Administration recommends that the Board authorize and direct Administration to proceed with an public administrative hearing under Public Contract Code section 4110, that the Board appoint Associate Superintendent Marcus Battle or his designee to serve as the hearing officer for the matter, that Mr. Battle hold the hearing and provide D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. notice of the hearing as required by law, that Mr. Battle, after hearing the evidence, render a decision including but not limited to what remedies under Public Contract Code section 4110 may be appropriate, and that the decision be presented to the Board for approval and adoption at the next Regular Board Meeting.
	 
	 
	 
Fiscal Impact:
Not Yet Applicable
	 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution #2011/2012-15: (i) authorizing and directing Administration to proceed with an public administrative hearing under Public Contract Code section 4110, (ii) appointing Associate Superintendent Marcus Battle or his designee to serve as the hearing officer for the matter, (iii) directing Mr. Battle to hold the hearing and provide D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. notice of the hearing as required by law, (iv) directing that Mr. Battle, after hearing the evidence, render a decision including but not limited to the appropriate remedy to be imposed, if any, under Public Contract Code section 4110, and (v) directing that Mr. Battle’s decision be presented to the Board for approval and adoption at the next Regular Board Meeting, or next available Board meeting.

Falk Construction, Inc. notice of the hearing as required by law, (iv) directing that Mr. Battle, after hearing the evidence, render a decision including but not limited to the appropriate remedy to be imposed, if any, under Public Contract Code section 4110, and (v) directing that Mr. Battleâs decision be presented to the Board for approval and adoption at the next Regular Board Meeting, or next available Board meeting.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.04
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
SUBJECT:
Approve the Work Experience Education (WEE) Program and Application 
	 
OVERVIEW:
In order for the East Side Union High School District to operate an approved Work Experience Education (WEE) Program, we need to submit a Plan and Application to the California Department of Education.  All of the minimum assurance requirements are included, as well as the required list of those authorized to sign work permits.
	 
New California Code of Regulations (5CCR) included WEE programmatic changes.  As of April 2011, 5 CCR section 10070 now clarifies information and details of required elements to the WEE Secondary District Plan, section 10071 clarifies information on assurances required on the Student Training Agreement, and section 10075 clarifies the type of credential required by a WEE teacher-coordinator.  Additionally, these regulation changes included the revision or work permit forms.  Updates work permit forms have been provided to each school site.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Work Experience Education (WEE) Program and application.

Item:  10.06
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona,  Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and George Sanchez, Coordinator of Student Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Inter-District Attendance Agreement with Lodi Unified School District
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District is requesting authorization to enter into an Inter-District Attendance Agreement with the Lodi Unified School District, pursuant to California Education Code Section 46600 and Assembly Bill 2444.
	 
The term of this agreement shall be effective October 5, 2011, and shall terminate on June 30, 2016.  An inter-district transfer permit issued under this agreement is only valid for one year.  A student who attends another school district other than his or her district of residence pursuant to an inter-district transfer permit under this agreement shall reapply annually for a new inter-district transfer permit each year.   The requirement to reapply for an inter-district transfer permit each school year does not apply to a student who is attending and enrolled in a school district other than his or her district of residence pursuant to an inter-district transfer permit and who will be entering grades 11 or 12 in the subsequent school year.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize entering into an Inter-District Attendance Agreement with Lodi Unified School District until June 30, 2016.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.02
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:            Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction;
                                    and Vida Branner, Director of Compensation and Classified Employee Relations
	 
SUBJECT:                    Ratify and Approve Tentative Agreement and Memorandum of Understanding Re:    
                                    Furlough Days (“MOU”) with the California School Employees Association, Chapter
                                    187, July 1, 2011 – June 30, 2012; Ratify and Approve Memorandum of
                                    Understanding with the California School Employees Association (CSEA),
                                    Chapter 187, Effective July 1, 2011 (the “Transportation MOU”)
	 
	 
Attached is a copy of the Tentative Agreement and MOU which include the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187, for the period July 1, 2011 - June 30, 2012.  Also attached is a copy of the Transportation MOU which includes proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187, effective July 1, 2011.  The Transportation MOU replaces Article 20.11 of the existing Collective Bargaining Agreement.  The District and the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 reached a tentative agreement on October 13, 2011, as reflected in the attached Tentative Agreement, and reached agreement on the MOU on that same date.  The agreement on the Transportation MOU was reached on October 25, 2011.  The Tentative Agreement, the MOU and the Transportation MOU were each ratified and approved by CSEA, Chapter 187, on November 1, 2011.  We are submitting these agreements to the Board of Trustees for ratification and approval.
In addition, provisions of AB 1200 require that school district disclose, at a public meeting, the cost that would be incurred by the implementation of a collective bargaining agreement.  In meeting the requirement, a public hearing was held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
As per attached AB1200 document
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
General, Special Education, and Adult Education Funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees, per compliance with AB1200, ratify the Tentative Agreement and MOU between the East Side Union High School District and the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187, for the period July 1, 2011 – June 30, 2012, and ratify the Transportation MOU effective July 1, 2011, through June 30, 2013.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.03
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:            Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
	 
SUBJECT:                    Approve Job Description and Salary Range for Classified Management Position of
                                    District Architect
	 
The District Architect will provide the District with technical level review of documentation and submittals, which include previous surveys and as-built drawings, as well as be responsible for ensuring that the District design guidelines are adhered to which will help mitigate costly design changes that the District has experienced in the past.  The District Architect would also be able to assist the Bond Team in overseeing the District’s Construction Managers and outside architects during both design and construction phases.  In addition, the District Architect would be filling an area that is currently lacking in regards to providing technical assistance to requests for additional add services and review of potential change orders.  These duties would not only reduce the cost of change orders but also the frequency of them.
	 
As Measure E Phase II projects are beginning and initial designs are being developed, there is an increased need for providing on-going technical assistance to the project architects as to the detailed assumptions that went into the Phase II project briefs that defined the individual project scopes of work.
	 
It is anticipated that the District Architect would be able to submit designs directly to the Division of State Architect and assist the District with land use and site planning issues which may have long and short range development impacts.
	 
This position is a 12 month Classified Management position at an annual salary range of $115,702 - $123,337.
	 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Obligation Bond Funds
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$115,702 - $123,337 per year
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the classified management job description and salary range for the classified management position of District Architect.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  12.04
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading and Adopt Amendment to Board Policy 3105 Fund Balance (GASB 54)
			 
			 
The Board Policy 3105, was adopted at the Board Meeting of June 28, 2011.  The following amendment to BP 3105 is offered to change the percentage of reserve that the district will maintain as a reserve for economic uncertainties is being changed from 3% to 6%. 
			 
The Board Bylaw 9310 allows the Board to review and approve this amendment as a “First Reading.”  Specifically, the bylaw states that “The Board may waive the second reading or may require an additional reading, if necessary.”The district is requesting that the second reading be waived because the change is only related to an adjustment in the minimum fund balance reserve for economic uncertainties.  The recommended change in BP3105 is reflective of the requirements of GASB 54 which requires an accompanying resolution at the time when the original board policy was adopted by the Governing Board. According to the district’s auditor, Vavrinek, Trine, and Day, the resolution should have been presented and approved at the time in which BP3105 was adopted, however, this did not occur.
			 
The District is recommending a change in the adopted reserve for economic uncertainties because the district now believes that maintaining a minimum reserve of 3% is not prudent in the current fiscal environment.  As a testament of this fact, please read the following excerpt from School Services of California:
			 
During times like these, as budgets are being cut and local agencies are required to do more with less, the question always comes up about reserves—is this the time to spend them or bolster them? Adequate reserves, and the cash component of reserves, are key to fiscal stability. What follows are our thoughts about adequate reserves for school districts, in good times and bad.
			 
What are Reserves For?
Reserves are a safety net that allow a district to meet its obligations, and are especially important in an environment of uncontrollable cost increases, volatile revenue sources, and other surprises that can and do happen. A district typically has some control over costs, but very little control over revenues, especially as the state tightens its belt and reduces the resources going to local districts. Reserves allow a district to have cash on hand to meet its obligations even when hit with unexpected financial turbulence.
			 
Remember that most financial problems are really multiyear problems and not one time. Reserves are one-time funds—once used, they are not replaced except by purposeful action of the district. Therefore, reserves can be used to carry a district through a year of financial problems until the district can make enough cuts in its budget to address the ongoing financial issues. It would take a significant amount of reserves to solve an ongoing budget problem, even temporarily, if no other actions are taken to right-size the budget.
			 
Districts that do not have adequate reserves to begin with are the first ones that get into financial trouble when the state cuts funding—and, unfortunately, there is a long history reflecting many periods of flat state funding and/or cuts to school districts.
			 
How Much in Reserves is Really Needed?
The Standards and Criteria has established a minimum reserve for Economic Uncertainties of 3% for most districts in the state depending on size. Smaller districts are required to have more than 3%, while larger districts in some instances are required to have less. That 3% is the minimum prudent level of reserves—with emphasis on the word "minimum." This means that districts that have additional risk factors need to have higher reserves. Here are some examples of possible risk factors:
Declining enrollment
Delays in cash receipts (for example, apportionment deferrals)
Other restricted district funds that may require unrestricted general fund contributions
Unstable labor relations
Dependence on property taxes ("basic aid" districts)
Debt service risks
Relatively small district size
History of deficit spending and/or projected future deficit spending
Reliance on one-time revenue sources
Exposure to significant one-time expenditures (such as inadequate resources for a facilities project or a large uninsured claim against the district)
			 
If any one or more of the above risk factors exist in your district, it would be prudent to set aside additional reserves beyond the state required minimum. Keep in mind that a 3% reserve covers only about seven or eight days of payroll for a district. Many districts have in place a Board policy that requires a higher reserve level—8%, 10%, or more. It would be a good idea to include some language in the policy that addresses how and when the reserves will be replenished, if there is an unforeseen situation that takes it below the Board-established minimum.
			 
For the 2009-10 fiscal year, the latest year for which there is state-certified data, unrestricted general fund balances as a percentage to the total general fund budget were:
Unified School Districts—10.40%
Elementary School Districts—16.83%
High School Districts—15.22%
			 
When balances from Fund 17 Special Reserve are added to the above expenditures, the percentages are:
Unified School Districts—11.28%
Elementary School Districts—19.05%
High School Districts—17.98%
			 
Conclusion
In setting a reserve level, the goal is to have the resources necessary to meet both planned and unplanned financial challenges, while spending as much of the current year's resources as possible on the current year's programs and students. This is a balancing act that will be unique to each district as it examines the risk factors that apply in order to determine how much is needed in reserves.
			 
One final thought: it would seem illogical that, during this time of state funding cuts, a district's reserves are found to be higher this year than before. However, it makes sense when you consider the one—time infusion of federal funds, the cuts in expenditures that have been made, and the actions taken to conserve cash when the state is holding onto your cash longer. Districts with higher reserves right now should not apologize for it—rather, you should give yourself a pat on the back if this is the case in your district. It means that your district has been strategic and prudent in managing its fiscal affairs during this very difficult time and is well prepared to handle the bumps in the road still to come.
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the amendment and adoption to Board Policy 3105 Fund Balance (GASB 54).

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  12.05
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-14 Committing Fund Balance in Accordance with GASB 54 
			 
The objective of GASB 54 is to enhance the usefulness of fund balance information by providing clearer fund balance classification that can be more consistently applied and by clarifying the existing governmental fund type definitions.  This resolution defines GASB 54 fund balance components, delegate's authority to Superintendent and/or their designee regarding designating uses of assigned funds, and the Board's fund balance policy with funds committed for a specific purpose. In regard to committed funds, this resolution defines that the ending fund balances in Fund 11, Fund 14, Fund 20, and Fund 71 for adult education, deferred maintenance, retiree benefits irrevocable trust, and irrevocable trust, respectively as committed for the purposes described. 
			 
This resolution further supports the Board commitment to effective and prudent fiscal management practices by maintaining a minimum fund balance for economic reserves of 6% of the District's general fund annual operating expenditures in each year of a three year multi-year projection. The Board will allow the fund balance to adjust to no less than 5% in the third year of such projections, which shall be recovered at the rate of .5% minimally each year.
			 
In order to be in compliance with the new GASB 54 requirements, the GASB 54 Resolution Approving Fund Balance Classification Assignment, Fund Balance Spending Order and Minimum Balance is being presented for approval.   
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-14 Committing Fund Balance in Accordance with GASB 54.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  13.01
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation/Update on the General Obligation Bond Program Funding Review
			 
The District’s bond consultant Mr. Dale Scott  from Dale Scott and Company has provided the district with an update of the district’s GO Bond potential as of November 2011.  Mr. Scott previously presented the Board with a  projection of GO Bond potential at the October 20, 2011 Governing Board meeting.  At that time, Mr. Scott indicated that the district could competitively offer $100 million in “current interest bonds” which would maximize the districts tax rate through 2020.  In other words, if the district were to competitively offer $100 million in current interest bonds, the district would be unable to draw down any additional borrowing authority until after calendar year 2020.  
			 
Since that time, Mr. Scott with the assistance of School Services of California have further reviewed the assessed valuation numbers for the district and have determined that the district’s competitive GO Bond potential is only $90 million.  If the district were to need more than $90 million, then the district would be required to issue ‘capital appreciation bonds” which would be a much more costly method of borrowing and would maximize the district’s maximum tax through 2034.  As an example, if the district were to issue $90 million in “current interest bonds” and $20 million in “capital appreciation bonds”,  the district would be at the maximum tax rate and unable to borrow again until calendar year 2034.  
			 
In any event, the district will be unable to borrow again until after calendar year 2020.  
			 
As a result of these findings, the district will recommend one of two alternatives for allocating  remaining measure E phase II project funding which will be both fiscally responsive to the changes in borrowing reality and also maximizes equity across sites.
items.item_text: Presentation/Update on the General Obligation Bond Program Funding Review - Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  13.02
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services in Consultation with SGI
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Measure E Forecast and Spending Plan
			 
			 
In 2008, voters of the East Side Union High School District approved Ballot Measure E, authorizing the District to levy up to $349 million for capital construction, consistent with the ballot language. The District’s Bond Advisors recently informed the Board that there may be limitations on future bond sales. As a result, the Board directed staff to prepare a plan that would account for a reduction in gross Measure E proceeds, while accounting for the District’s equity allocation goals.
							 
In February 2009, the Board of Trustees approved a $349 million Equity-Allocation plan for the District’s 11 campuses. The Board concurrently authorized 31 Phase I projects, valued at $130 million, and enabled acquisition of the Calero High School site for $20 million. The allocations for Mt. Pleasant and Calero High Schools have since been augmented with Board approval, bringing the total budget for Phase I projects to $161 million.
							 
The February 2009 Board action further defined two additional tiers of projects: those that were “on-deck” for implementation (Phase II) and those that would be implemented subject to availability of funds after completion of Phases I & II. The Board has subsequently authorized proceeding with Phase II projects, valued at $86 million.
							 
To date, the District has secured approximately $174.5 million for its Measure E capital construction program. With this funding, the District can expect the following:
Completion of Phase I projects, 
Acquisition of the Calero High School site, 
50% completion of the Measure E Information Technology program
							 
Assuming current plans remain unaltered, at the conclusion of Phase II there would be significant equity distribution gaps. Given limitations on available funding going forward, the District should consider two alternative scenarios through which Equity Allocation goals can be maximized: 1) moving forward with a limited Phase III in the amount of $13 million, focused on closing equity distribution gaps or 2) redressing equity distribution by realigning project budgets in Phase II (and Phase I to a limited extent). 
							 
A plan that includes Phase III (Alternative A) will require approval of bond sales totaling $110 million (including a Capitol Appreciation Bond in the amount of $20 million). A plan based on a realigned Phase II (Alternative B) will require $90 million in bond sales (and will not require a Capitol Appreciation Bond). In either scenario, the District’s goal is to achieve equity distribution of Measure E funding at 80% or higher for all 11 campuses.
FISCAL IMPACT:
$264.5 Million 
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees: 1) Adopt Measure E Bond Program Implementation Plan Alternative B (without $20M CAB) and 2) Authorize staff to proceed with realignment of Measure E Bond projects, adjusting project budgets to maximize equity distribution based on total available funds.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees: 1) Adopt Measure E Bond Program Implementation Plan Alternative B (without $20M CAB) and 2) Authorize staff to proceed with realignment of Measure E Bond projects, adjusting project budgets to maximize equity distribution based on total available funds.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  13.03
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services in Consultation with SGI
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Measure G Site Improvement/Deferred Maintenance Plan
			 
			 
In 2002, voters of the East Side Union High School District approved Ballot Measure G, authorizing the District to levy up to $298 million for capital construction, consistent with the ballot language. At its meeting of September 15, 2011, East Side’s Board of Trustees approved a “Deferred Maintenance” initiative to be funded from remaining Measure G proceeds, as follows:
166 individual projects, 
on 13 sites, and
with an estimated combined cost of $27.9 million
Consistent with the mandate of the Measure G program, these projects are focused on improving safety & security and reducing operating costs through repairing & equipping aging sites and facilities. This investment is essential for addressing critical needs and ensuring the long term value of the District’s physical assets. After this Deferred Maintenance initiative, approximately $12 million will remain unencumbered in Measure G.
			 
Upon further consideration, the same objectives may be served and the value of the Deferred Maintenance initiative will be enhanced by combining it with site improvements that include field upgrades, capital equipment replacement for food services district-wide, and updating of civil infrastructure surveys for all sites. The projected cost of this additional scope is $5.6 million. Other similar scope will be presented for consideration at a later date, subject to availability of funding.
			 
Attached is a preliminary implementation plan that illustrates how the Deferred Maintenance and immediate Site Improvement will be accomplished together under a single initiative that:
starts immediately, 
provides recognizable results throughout, 
substantially completes major projects within 2 calendar years,
brings all projects to conclusion within 3 calendar years, and
provides a clear expression of improved site conditions throughout the District. 
			 
Through identified savings and efficiencies that may be realized by combining Deferred Maintenance and Site Improvement scope, the added cost for the initiative is $4.6 million. As an added benefit, it is anticipated that upon completion, this initiative will save the District approximately 20% on its annual facilities maintenance and operation cost.
			 
Staff will be on hand for a brief presentation and to address questions.
			 
Fiscal Impact:
$32.5 million
			 
Funding Source:
Measure G
			 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:1) Approve a single initiative merging the previously approved “Deferred Maintenance” projects with the proposed immediate “Site Improvement” scope, 2) Authorize staff to proceed with the General Approach illustrated in the Preliminary Master Schedule (attached), and 3) Approve additional funding of $4.6 million from available Measure G funds to be applied to the “Site Improvement Initiative”, for a combined budget of $32.5 million.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:1)Approve a single initiative merging the previously approved “Deferred Maintenance” projects with the proposed immediate “Site Improvement” scope, 2)Authorize staff to proceed with the General Approach illustrated in the Preliminary Master Schedule (attached), and 3)Approve additional funding of $4.6 million from available Measure G funds to be applied to the “Site Improvement Initiative”, for a combined budget of $32.5 million.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of October 2011
				 
				 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of October 2011, in response to board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
